title: Why do we continue to use fossil fuel, when it is so dirty? - Quora

response.answer_text: If we put aside the very strong fossil fuel industry lobby… (1) Inadequate infrastructure. U.S. power plants were designed back when coal, oil, and natural gas were the only choices. This includes power plants that have come online in the past decade (We’re not even building nuclear power plants as we once did). Centralized power-producing plants are not the appropriate model for renewable energy sources, which means that it’s not just power plants that are out of date. Energy producers are also energy distributors. It’s likely that their business will eventually be in acquisition and distribution of power from renewable sources. But this is quite a way off for some regions of the U.S. and less so for behemoths like California. When considering motorized transportation, infrastructure is still lagging significantly. Most regions do not have charging stations at adequate intervals for electric vehicles. However, railways are in the process of becoming electrified. For commuter lines, this means faster transit times and more frequent trains— perhaps, enticing motorists to get out of their cars for some transportation needs. (2) Not-quite-there renewable energy technology. While the technologies for renewable energy have made tremendous strides in the past decade, they still have two problems (that will go away rather soon— maybe another decade): (a) They are mostly a little above the price point that many consumers are willing to pay. (b) They do not produce a steady flow of energy. The first will resolve itself as the technology gets cheaper to build, use, and maintain. The second will resolve itself as massive energy storage (e.g., “batteries”) gains the capacity to store energy from solar and wind sources and push it through the infrastructure in a metered way. Elon Musk (of Tesla fame) is dedicating substantial resources to R&D for better energy storage. Volvo has committed to having all its models run with an electric power chain by 2019–2021. Both of these issues are being addressed with a demand-side economic push. They can also be addressed with federal and state environmental protections. Energy-related businesses manage to find the talent to make the breakthroughs when there’s unmet demand and/or an imperative to improve. As of 2017, we’re seeing a feverish national effort to reverse environmental protections and to defund R&D for renewable energy technology. Major corporations have said that they still intend to move toward renewable energy sources and to reduce overall energy consumption. It’s their future and they want to be prepared. CEOs from some of these corporations intend to fulfill the Paris Agreement commitments that the U.S. has made— with or without White House concurrence. In fact, there are major energy-producing corporations that have been outspoken in their opposition to withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement. As of yesterday, the POTUS reiterated what he’s been saying for a long time: Maybe he’ll work something out regarding the U.S. withdrawal; maybe he won’t. His position has been that the Agreement is “unfair” to the U.S. However, most of the list of grievances he’s stated are not true. It’s possible that he’s based his assumptions on the comments of alt-right talk show hosts; sometimes what he says is a direct (uncited) quote. It’s pretty obvious that he has not read the substance of the Agreement or the “executive summary.” With Scott Pruitt in charge of the EPA (a federal agency that he sued 13 times), it will be a complicated dance before the US would withdraw its withdrawal from the Agreement. Meanwhile, we continue to use fossil fuels because we do not have adequate production and distribution of renewable energy.

There is energy past, energy present and energy future. It would be nice to think that we could learn to live on energy present and future; but, we are addicted to things which require energy past.
